case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 80 of 1963 filed by special leave from Punjab High Court judgment dated March 26, 1963 in Criminal Misc. No. 186 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 80 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 26, 1963, of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Misc. No. 186 of 1963.

facts.text: Detenu Makhan Singh Tarsikka's Habeas Corpus petition dismissed by Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The detenu Makhan Singh Tarsikka whose Habeas Corpus petition has been dismissed by the Punjab High Court, has brought this appeal before us by special leave.

facts.text: F.I.R. filed on 22nd October 1962 at Police Station Jandiala alleging offences under sections 307, 324, 364 and 367 I.P.C. by persons including appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on the 22nd October, 1962, F.I.R., was filed at the Police Station, Jandiala, alleging that offences under sections 307, 324, 364 and 367 I.P.C. had been companymitted by certain persons including the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant arrested on 25th October 1962 pursuant to investigation of F.I.R.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the investigation which companymenced on receipt of the said F.I.R., the appellant was arrested on the 25th October, 1962.

facts.text: Emergency declared by the President on 26th October 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th October, 1962, Emergency was declared by the President.

facts.text: Appellant transferred to judicial custody of Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Amritsar on 1st November 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On the 1st November, 1962, the appellant was transferred to judicial custody of the Sub- Divisional Magistrate, Amritsar.

facts.text: Appellant interviewed by about nine persons between 3rd November to 19th November 1962 while in jail custody.

anchor.surface_text: Whilst the appellant was in jail custody, he was allowed to interview his friends and about nine persons interviewed him between 3rd November to the 19th November, 1962.

facts.text: Order of detention passed against appellant on 20th November 1962 under Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On the 20th November, 1962, an order of detention was passed against the appellant under Rule 30 1  b  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962  hereinafter called the Rules .

facts.text: Detention order served on appellant on 21st November 1962 while in jail custody and removed to jail at Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: This order was served on the appelant on the 21st November, 1962 and it appears he was removed to the jail at Hissar.

facts.text: Appellant brought back to Amritsar on 30th January 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th January, 1963, he was brought back to Amritsar,

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition on 9th February 1963.

anchor.surface_text: and on the 9th February 1963 he filed the present writ petition.

facts.text: Petitioner alleged grounds of detention vague, concocted and false.

anchor.surface_text: In his petition which was filed by the appellant, the main allegation which he made in challenging the validity of his detention was that the grounds set up in the order of detention were very vague, companycocted and totally false.

facts.text: Detention order stated appellant indulging in activities prejudicial to Defence of India by propaganda against joining forces and contributing to National Defence Fund.

anchor.surface_text: The detention order had stated that the appellant was detained because he was found to be indulging in activities prejudicial to the Defence of India and Civil Defence by making propaganda against joining the armed and civil defence forces and by-urging people number to companytribute to the National Defence Fund.

facts.text: Appellant filed additional affidavit on 4th March 1963 alleging in confinement before emergency on 26th October 1962 showing allegations false.

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th March, 1963, the appellant made an additional affidavit in which be urged that the fact that the depone it was in companyfinement before the declaration of emergency on the 26th October, 1962 and the Chinese invasion, clearly showed that the allegations against the deponent were false and companycocted.

facts.text: Appellant filed third affidavit on 6th March 1963 alleging political activities disliked by high-ups and police enmity.

anchor.surface_text: On the 6th March, 1963, the appellant filed a third affidavit in which he stated that his political activities as a member of the Legislative Assembly were disliked by the High--ups.

facts.text: Respondent's counter-affidavits stated appellant instigated prejudicial activities during nine jail interviews 3rd-19th Nov 1962.

anchor.surface_text: It was in one of these affidavits that the res- pondent brought out the fact that the appellant had nine interviews in jail between the 3rd November to 19th November, 1962 and. the information received by the respondent was that during these interviews, the appellant instigated the persons who saw him, to companymit prejudicial activities.

facts.text: Punjab High Court rejected contentions that detention malafide due to prior arrest and pending criminal case under s.307 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who heard the habeas companypus petition filed by the appellant, rejected both these Contentions. In the result, he held that the appellant had failed to make out a case that his detention was illegal, and so, the writ petition was dismissed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held service of detention order on 21st Nov 1962 invalid as appellant was in jail custody.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the service of the order of detention on the appellant whilst he was in ail custody is invalid.

facts.text: Appeal heard on October 11, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: K. Kaushal, Senior Deputy Advocate-General for the State of Punjab and B. R. G. K. Achar, for the respondent. October 11, 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal and set aside detention order on ground service invalid under Rule 30(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed and the order of detention passed against the appellant is set aside On the ground that the service of the order is invalid and is outside the scope of Rule 30 1  b  of the Rules.

facts.text: Criminal case under s.307 IPC pending against appellant at time of detention.

anchor.surface_text: It was also argued before the High Court on his behalf that since a criminal case under s. 307 I.P.C. was pending against him at the relevant time,

facts.text: Appellant later granted bail in criminal case subject to detention order.

anchor.surface_text: In fact, we were told that after the criminal case pending against the appellant was transferred from  1  1964 4 S.C.R. 9118. Amritsar to a companyrt of companypetent jurisdiction in U.P. the said companyrt has allowed the appellants application for ball,

facts.text: Petitioner's plea of mala fides rejected by Supreme Court for lack of material.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think Mr. Garg can be permitted to raise that point in the present appeal, because we find that adequate material has number been produced by the appellant in support of his plea in the present proceedings.

issues.text: Whether the service of the detention order on the appellant when he was already in jail custody is valid under Rule 30(1)(b) of the Defence of India Rules

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant, Mr. Garg has urged that the service of the order of detention which was effected on the 21st November, 1962 is illegal and in support of his argument he has relied on a recent decision of this Court in Rameshwar Shaw v. The District Magistrate Burdwan Another 1 . Mr. Garg points out that the material words used in section 3 1  of the Preventive Detention Act, 1960  No. 4 of 1960   hereinafter called the Act  which were construed by this Court in the case of Rameshwar Shaw 1  are substantially the same as in Rule 30 1  of the rules with which the present appeal is concerned

issues.text: Whether the wider scope of orders under Rule 30(1) makes any difference to the interpretation of the operative provisions of Rule 30(1) in relation to detention on a person in custody

anchor.surface_text: But the question which we have to consider is does this fact make any difference to the interpretation of the operative provisions of Rule 30 1  in relation to detention? In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in the negative. Rule 30 1  b , like s. 3 1  a , clearly postulates that an order can be made under it only where it is shown that but for the imposition of the said detention

issues.text: Whether the detention order was passed malafide

anchor.surface_text: it was urged by the appellant that the order of his detention had been passed malafide and his detention was sought to be supported on the ground that he had been arrested on the 25th October, 1962, and so, it would not be rationally possible to allege against him that he had indulged in the prejudicial activities mentioned in the said order.

issues.text: Whether the making of the detention order itself is invalid because the appellant was in jail custody at the time

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg also contended that the making of the order of detention itself is invalid, because at the time when the order was made the appropriate authority knew that the appellant was in jail, and so, the order passed was not justified and is, therefore, invalid under Rule 30 1 .

issues.text: Whether detention and prosecution of the same person can proceed simultaneously

anchor.surface_text: the problem which the Patna High Court has considered in that case was sought to be raised before us by Mr. Garg, but since we have come to the conclusion that the service of the order of detention on the appellant whilst he was in jail custody is invalid, we do not propose to deal with that question.

issues.text: Whether it was open to the detaining authority to detain the appellant under Rule 30(1)(b) when a criminal case under s.307 IPC was pending against him

anchor.surface_text: It was also argued before the High Court on his behalf that since a criminal case under s. 307 I.P.C. was pending against him at the relevant time, it was not open to the detaining authority to detain him under Rule 30 1  b  of the-Rules. The learned Judge who heard the habeas corpus petition filed by the appellant, rejected both these contentions.

Procedure Code and the other under Rule 3O 1  b .

arguments.claim: service of detention order on person in jail custody invalid under Rule 30(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this argument is well-founded and must be accepted. In the case of Rameshwar Shaw 1  this Court construed s. 3 1  of the Act and held that the said provision necessarily postulates that a person sought to be detained would be free to act in a prejudicial manner if he is not detained.

arguments.claim: wider scope of Rule 30(1) clauses does not alter requirement for freedom under Rule 30(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: But the question which we have to consider is does this fact make any difference to the interpretation of the operative provisions of Rule 30 1  in relation to detention? In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in the negative.

arguments.claim: service on jail custody person effects double detention not intended by Rule 30(1)(b)

anchor.surface_text: The service of a detention order on a person who is already in jail ,custody virtually seeks to effectuate what may be called a double detention and such double detention is not intended either by s. 3 1  a  or by Rule 30 1  b  it is plainly unnecessary and outside the purview of both the provisions.

arguments.claim: contentions of malafides and pending criminal case rejected; detention not illegal

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who heard the habeas corpus petition filed by the appellant, rejected both these Contentions. In the result, he held that the appellant had failed to make out a case that his detention was illegal, and so, the writ petition was dismissed.

arguments.claim: plea of mala fides cannot be raised due to lack of adequate material and improper pleadings

anchor.surface_text: We do not think Mr. Garg can be permitted to raise that point in the present appeal, because we find that adequate material has not been produced by the appellant in support of his plea in the present proceedings.

holdings.text: The service of the order of detention on the appellant whilst he was in jail custody is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we must hold that the service of the order of detention on the appellant whilst he was in ail custody is invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 30(1)(b) postulates that the person must be free to carry out prejudicial activities absent detention, analogous to Preventive Detention Act s.3(1)(a) as held in Rameshwar Shaw; person in custody cannot be so predicated.

holdings.text: The wider scope of Rule 30(1) does not make any difference to the interpretation of the operative provisions of Rule 30(1) in relation to detention on a person in custody.

anchor.surface_text: But the question which we have to consider is does this fact make any difference to the interpretation of the operative provisions of Rule 30 1  in relation to detention? In our opinion, the answer to this question must be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Operative part of Rule 30(1)(b) identical to PDA s.3(1)(a); requires freedom to act prejudicially regardless of other clauses allowing alternative orders.

holdings.text: Service of a detention order on a person already in jail custody effectuates double detention which is not intended by Rule 30(1)(b) or PDA s.3(1)(a), is unnecessary and outside their purview.

anchor.surface_text: The service of a detention order on a person who is already in jail ,custody virtually seeks to effectuate what may be called a double detention and such double detention is number intended either by s. 3 1  a  or by Rule 30 1  b  it is plainly unnecessary and outside the purview of both the provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation; provisions aimed at preventing prejudicial acts by free persons, not adding detention to existing custody.

holdings.text: Argument that under-trial prisoner can carry prejudicial activities via jail interviews requiring detention under Rule 30(1)(b) rejected; alternatives available under Punjab Detenus Rules 13/19 or DIR Rule 30(1)(h).

anchor.surface_text: It was also argued by the learned Dy. Advocate-General that in the case of an under-trial prisoner who is entitled to interview his friends or relatives under rules framed in that behalf. it would be possible for him to send out messages and thereby carry on his prejudicial activities in an indirect way,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific rules regulate interviews with supervision; Rule 30(1)(h) allows conduct regulation without detention.

holdings.text: Plea of mala fides cannot be raised in this appeal due to lack of adequate material and improper pleadings.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think Mr. Garg can be permitted to raise that point in the present appeal, because we find that adequate material has number been produced by the appellant in support of his plea in the present proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Insufficient evidence produced; mala fides requires proper pleadings at trial stage for respondent to rebut; not sustainable on prior arrest alone.

holdings.text: A plea of mala fides must always be made by proper pleadings at the trial stage.

anchor.surface_text: A plea of mala fides must always be made by proper pleadings at the trial stage, so that the respondent has an opportunity to meet the said pleadings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural requirement to allow rebuttal; cannot be based on special leave petition averments.

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the order of detention passed against the appellant is set aside on the ground that the service of the order is invalid and outside the scope of Rule 30(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed and the order of detention passed against the appellant is set aside On the ground that the service of the order is invalid and is outside the scope of Rule 30 1  b  of the Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct consequence of invalid service holding.
